reviewText:
Despite the amazing Artwork, there is no gameplay here. Unlike other, more recent clickers, there isn't really much to do. The game is extremely grindy and with Grindy I mean having an option to select between one of three quests, although alternating, which comes with a quest reward, a time frame which the quest will take up and how much of your Thirst for Adventure it costs you.

Each day you get 100 minutes worth of Quest for Adventure, after which you can use real currency to replenish the Quest for Adventure or wait till the day ticks over. The game lets you 'work' for the city guard, which basically is just a way to send your character for an hour or two to work, earning money.

More interesting features like Pets are hidden behind a level barrier, requiring you to go as far as level 75 to unlock pets. And you do so by going on the aforementioned quests. At the beginning those take mere minutes and even though there is a fight at the end of it, you have no control over the fight. Just watch your portrait send some cheap effect at their portrait as their (and your) HP bar goes down.

The game is awfully passive, even for a clicker and I think there are better clickers on Steam that actually engage you, even though you only click on things. This game however, is so passive... its boring. Click on quest, wait 3 minutes, click on new quest. Rinse and repeat.. maybe after a few weeks you'll be high enough in your level to unlock Dungeons, pets and other features.

Also when you are told your level 8 character is stronger than over 60% of the populace, then one has to question what the point is of playing. It seems awfully pointless to me.

reviewText:
Shakes and Fidget is a very fun and compelling game as long as you know what you're getting into. Namely, it's an idle starical free to play RPG. You can go on quests, collect loot, do PVP, and eventually enter dungeons and build a fortress. The game is very light hearted in its writing and humor. It is very much a parody of a lot of modern RPGs, especially World of Warcraft. I like the art style in particular. It's very ... German if that makes any sense.

When you go on a quest, there is a timer that counts down until the quest is completed. And this is where the idle aspect of the game fits in. This is a small game designed to run in the background while you do other things. I usually had my character going on quests in the background while I played WoW and FF14. I honestly have had a lot of fun leveling and gearing my character and pitting her against other people's characters in the arena. And the dungeons are actually tough which is something I kind of miss in modern MMOs! There is a premium currency in the form of mushrooms, but I never felt forced to spend money on any as the game is pretty forgiving in giving you mushrooms as you play, allowing you to go on extra quests or do an extra arena if you so desire. And when you decided you've had enough for the day, you can even assign your character to guard duty so you can continue to earn gold even when you've turned the game off.

Overall, I have had a lot of fun with this game and I highly recommend everyone at least give it a try.

(4.8 / 10)

Although I have given a 'Not Recommened' rating to this game, it is fairly boarder line.


Pros:
- The graphical, 2d art-style is amusing, and is filled with pop-culture references.

- The rankings are linear enough that you can get a 'better than XX% of players' number. Extremly satisfying to move up the ranks.

- The gear system, though not extensive or stategic, does offer you a sense of progression.


Cons:
- Interactions and combat are shallow. Combat, for example, is simply rolling the dice and telling you the result. 'Adventuring' is the same way.

- Counters for various tasks can get tedious. For example, after finishing a match of PVP, you must wait a couple of minutes before you can begin a new round. When the combat itself is uniteresting, this makes it feel kind of slugish.


Other Questions:

Is it P2W?
No. Although there is a paid currency, it is very unabtrusive to the gameplay.

Is it anywhere near as good as the trailer implied?
Absolutely not. The trailler offered me a bit of hype, but of course, a trailer is just a trailer.


Overal: I would say this game is at least a way to fill time. However, there are far better games out there, so I don't neccisarly recommend you pick this game up.

Let's get one thing out of the way right away. This is NOT a good game. In fact, it is barely a game at all. It is just a series of timers with an illusion of a game. The combat in the game is automatic. There are no skills, no strategy, your characters just take turns attacking each other with basic attacks until one person dies. Whoever has the highest stats and higher level wins. Unless you get screwed over by the random number generator.

I DO NOT personally recommend this game at all.

With that said......the game is addicting and in a strange way fun. And honestly, if you want to play something while browsing the internet or if you have an office job where you are just looking for something to do to pass the time while you work. You could do worse then Shakes and Fidget. You can quest, unlock and conquer dungeons, fight other player's virtual NPC, join guilds and create or raid other player's guild fortresses. There is plenty of content there if you don't mind the fact that the gameplay is so shallow.

Also, the game IS made to try and get you to buy mushrooms with real world money,  But, I wouldn't call it Pay-To-Win. You can get mushrooms through questing(guaranteed drop for first quest of day and a rare drop after that) and all equipment and items can be gotten by playing through the game normally. Mushrooms are just a way for people with no patience to level up faster and get equipment quicker.

reviewText: This is the best idling game I have ever played. If you go into it expecting some grand rpg adventure like Skyrim, don't. You will be dissapointed. If you go into it only expecting some crappy idler game like cookie clicker, you will be surprised by the strategic depth it offers over pretty much all idlers. You must make many decisions, such as whether to use a legendary item with a ton of luck to aid your dps, or instead go for more reliable damage from a smaller amount of your primary stat. Every time you go into the arena, you try your luck (and your stats!) against other players. If you enjoy minmaxing, you will find a lot of joy from this game, as there's enough depth to play the game's systems to your advantage in a satisfying manner. Fortresses are pretty fun, as while I expected some crappy farmville-esque deal, in reality I was pleasantly surprised by a simple yet intuitive secondary game where you could aquire gems to further boost the abilities of your character. With the goal of making this review not just a lengthy list of the game's features, I will simply say that this is a fantastic game that you should probably try out for yourself. The artwork and comedy is very tongue in cheek, and the experience as a whole when playing is quite enjoyable. Thank you for reading my crappy review of this not so crappy game, and have fun playing!

Combat is automated, with the option to skip.
Despite Steam showing 1-3K players online, the overall playerbase population is low.
Most players do not speak english.
The game is simple, and boring. To describe this game in one word: Monotony.
In my opinion, it's not rewarding, entertaining, engaging nor worth my time.

reviewText:
Shakes and Fidget is a fantasy-themed satirical 2D MMORPG that combines typical RPG features such as quests, dungeons, mounts, crafting, and PvP, with humor, witty lines, and a whole lot of sarcasm in a cartoony visual novel style game.

Strap on your armor, hop on your cow, and take a stroll through the magical and satirical world of Shakes and Fidget, a free-to-play 2D visual novel style MMORPG that aims to tickle your funny bones. Create your own cartoony hero from 8 iconic races and 3 playable classes. Embark on absurd quests for the local townsfolk and journey to dangerous corners of the realm to take on killer monster rabbits or sulky tauruses for gold, glory, and honor. Equip your character with thousands of comically-named items such as “Dog Tags of the Fool” or “The Forbidden Book: Rated M for Mature,” that can be embedded with your choice of gemstones for added bonuses. Construct your very own fortress and defend it from attacks or challenge other players in the Arena to eventually reach the top spot in the Hall of Fame.

Shakes and Fidget Key Features:

Fun And Funny– the game pokes fun at typical MMORPG scenarios through sarcastic and witty dialog that will have fans of the genre cracking up every time.

Cartoony Characters – create your own comic book style characters from a surprisingly large choice of 8 races and 3 classes.

Thousands of Items – equip your hero with thousands of comically-named weapons, armor, and accessories.

PvP System – challenge other players to battle in the Arena or lay siege to their personal fortresses.

Multi-Platform Gaming – seamlessly transition from killing harmless mobs on your PC to killing even more harmless mobs on your mobile device.

It's a Game worth playing so give it a go!

At first, I thought this game sounded cool. It looked like a fun, cartoony RPG that had a feel like computerized Munchkin. Unfortunately, once I started playing, I realized that this game is unbelievably boring.

This game seems to consist of perpetual grinding to reach some unacheivable level in the hopes that the game might eventually get interesting. All you do is accept quests, wait five minutes for it to load, and then watch a fight play out (a fight which you have no control over) and then you go and do it all again. Or, if you're feeling adventurous, you can go to the Arena and get paired against another player who hopelessly, hilariously outguns you, and lose twice the honor you gained in your previous NPC fights. You can buy weapons, armor, and potions that up your stats, but they're expensive and give barely-noticeable boons. Supposedly, you can start building a fortress, or go fight in dungeons, but it won't give me any fortress points to start building or keys to start pillaging dungeons.

This game seems entirely pointless to me. All I end up doing is checking emails while I wait for fights to load. The only props I can give this game is that the artwork is legitimately beautiful--you can stare at it for ten minutes while you wait for your fights to load.

1.5 out of 10

This is a click farm game that you can find on Facebook. You choose from 3 classes and 8 races to make your character.

Simple web comic quality.

CONS

The in-game cash currency is called Mushrooms. You go to a shady dealer to pay cash for shrooms.

You need to use 1 Mushroom (cash currency) just to refresh the shop.

3 Classes
Mage, Warrior and Scout

8 races
Orc (Strength +1, Dexterity -1)
Elf (Strength -1, Dexterity +2, Constitution -1)
Gnome (Strength -1, Dexterity +3, Intelligence -1, Constitution -1)

Human (No changes)

Dark Elf (Strength -2, Dexterity +2, Intelligence +1, Constitution -1)
Goblin (Strength -2, Dexterity +2, Constitution -1, Luck +1)

You just hit the enemies with automatically. No skill or challenge.

3 hours in review:
So far I enjoy the the game a lot. It's pretty simple and nothing is too challenging. The artwork is a bit cartoonish which I personally don't care for much. There is one character that is in the Stable that scares the ♥♥♥♥ out of me. It looks terrifying.

The help button on the game just gives you links to other things instead of being a mini guide in-game to help. It would be great to have a little help tab on each page" to explain what it's for and what things do.

I can tell I will put quite a few hours into this game. I will update this review later.

25 active hours in:
This game has become quite boring. It was fun at first because it was simple and quick to play when you don't have much time. But things quickly slowed down when getting near level 20. I've made 4 accounts to try different classes and such and the warrior seems to be very good. The ranger sucks because almost every piece of equipment in the shops take away dexterity.. which is the primary thing to upgrade for ranger. The prices of items go up dramatically with it often costing "mushrooms" which you can collect over time easily.. but can just use real money instead of course. There is a fortress activity that you can do at level 25 but progress has been so slow and it's just not interesting to get on and do quests or anything anymore. Supposedly if you get to level 75 you can get pets?? How on earth are you supposed to get 75? It's difficult to get level 20!

I recommend this game if you don't have a lot of time to get into a difficult game. It becomes a bit tedious after awhile though. The layout of the buttons and things are difficult to learn at first. As a graphic designer
date: it's all a bit frustrating to try and figure out what things do what without much explanation.\n\n4/10"

reviewText:
3 hours in review:
So far I enjoy the the game a lot. It's pretty simple and nothing is too challenging. The artwork is a bit cartoonish which I personally don't care for much. There is one character that is in the Stable that scares the ♥♥♥♥ out of me. It looks terrifying.

The layout of the game is a bit cluttered with art and not much explaination. There are tips that pop up but they aren't completely clear on things. The help button on the game just gives you links to other things instead of being a mini guide in-game to help. It would be great to have a little help tab on each page" to explain what it's for and what things do.

I can tell I will put quite a few hours into this game. I will update this review later.

25 active hours in:
This game has become quite boring. It was fun at first because it was simple and quick to play when you don't have much time. But things quickly slowed down when getting near level 20. I've made 4 accounts to try different classes and such and the warrior seems to be very good. The ranger sucks because almost every piece of equipment in the shops take away dexterity.. which is the primary thing to upgrade for ranger. The prices of items go up dramatically with it often costing "mushrooms" which you can collect over time easily.. but can just use real money instead of course. There is a fortress activity that you can do at level 25 but progress has been so slow and it's just not interesting to get on and do quests or anything anymore. Supposedly if you get to level 75 you can get pets?? How on earth are you supposed to get 75? It's difficult to get level 20!

I recommend this game if you don't have a lot of time to get into a difficult game. It becomes a bit tedious after awhile though. The layout of the buttons and things are difficult to learn at first. As a graphic designer
date: it's all a bit frustrating to try and figure out what things do what without much explanation.\n\n4/10"

- A very short part of the clans will ask for resources for you to enter the clan, you might actually get scammed by that.
- No sound on the game, just when you are in a fight or click to go to a certain location.

There aren't that many cons, but there are some pros that make this game enjoyable

- 3 classes, each one of them are completly different, different items, different stats and different special abilities.
- Good variation in races, each one of those are different on skills that might make your character strong or weak on the start of your progress. (I made a guide helping you out choosing the correct Race+Class, here it is: My Guide
- If you go away, you can leave your character doing missions or on Work Hours, so you get rewards when you come back.
- The community is not toxic, except for the clan scamming, which is very rare to happen.
- Big diversity on enemies, dungeons and items.
- Balanced quest rewards and ranking system.

It is a free game, however dont expect this game to be like the most popular games today.
